meta.hint: Some words are alike. They go together in a group. eg. Red, Green, and blue go together in the colors group.
meta.question: Find the odd one out  from the group of words.

meta.hint:
"Some words are alike but have differences in meaning. Those differences are called Shades of meaning.
Example - Walking and Running .
They both are ways to move, but running is faster than walking."
meta.question: Identifying the difference  between related words.
Select the antonym of the word in bold.
meta.hint: "Antonyms are words with the opposite meaning. Example -  big, little."

meta.question: Select the synonym of the word in bold.
meta.hint:
"Synonyms are words with the same or 
almost the same meaning. eg. Dad and 
Father."

An adjective is a word that tells you about a person, place, animal or thing.
Some adjectives tell you how many.
eg. Kim sees two trees. I have three dogs.
meta.question: Complete the sentence  using number words to match the picture.

meta.hint:
A noun names a person, animal, place, or, thing.
Some nouns name a person. eg. girl, boy.
Some nouns name an animal. eg. duck, cat.
Some nouns name a place. eg. park, school.
Some nouns name a thing. eg. hat, train
meta.question: Complete the sentence to match the picture.

meta.hint:
A prefix can be added to the beginning of a word to make a new word. eg. redo = redo
A suffix can be added to the end of a word to make a new word. eg. help+ful = helpful
The prefix re- means again.
The prefix un- means not or the opposite of.
The suffix -ful means full of.
The suffix -less means without.
meta.question: Understand the word with prefix or suffix to tell the its meaning.

blocks.name: Understand words with Prefixes and Suffixes

meta.question: Complete the sentence with the right suffix or prefix.
meta.hint:
"A prefix can be added to the beginning of a word to make a new word. eg. redo = redo
A suffix can be added to the end of a word to make a new word. eg. help+ful = helpful
The prefix re- means again.
The prefix un- means not or the opposite of.
The suffix -ful means full of.
The suffix -less means without.
"

blocks.name: Use words with Prefixes and Suffixes
Use context to identify the meaning of a word

meta.hint:
"If you don't know the meaning of a word, look for context clues.
They are nearby words that help you figure out the meaning of a new word.
eg. Megan was glum when her best friend moved away.
You can guess that 'glum' means 'sad'. "
meta.question: Use nearby words or context to identify the  meaning of a word.
Can you identify this?

meta.hint:
A subject pronoun tells who is doing something. It is usually at the beginning of the sentence. The subject pronouns are I, you, he, she, it, we, and they. Example -. I met Rick. Example - They helped Stan.
An object pronoun comes after an action verb. The object pronouns are me, you, him, her, it, us, and them. Example - Rick met me. Example - Stan helps them.
meta.question: Complete the sentence with the best pronoun.

meta.hint:
Possessive pronouns take the place of possessive nouns. They show who owns something or has something.
Example - The ball belongs to Ron. It is his (Ron's) ball.
My, your, his, her, its, our and there are possessive pronouns. They can also be called possessive adjectives.
meta.question: Select the correct Possessive Pronoun.

meta.hint:
A common noun names a type of person, animal, place or thing. A common noun starts with a lowercase letter, unless it is the first word in a sentence. Example - cat, girl, park
A proper noun is a special name for one person, animal, place or thing. A proper noun always starts with a capital letter. Example - Max, Jane, Jackson Park Max is the name of one cat. Jane is the name of one girl. Jackson Park is the name of one park.
meta.question: Select the proper noun.

meta.hint:
A noun names a person, animal, place or thing.
Some nouns name a person. Example - girl, boy
Some nouns name an animal. Example - duck, cat
Some nouns name a place. Example - park, zoo
Some nouns name a thing. Example - hat, train
meta.question: Identify the correct noun.

meta.hint:
Possessive Nouns show belonging or owning. Add -'s to make a noun a Possessive noun.
eg. That was Tom's project.
meta.question: Select the possessive noun.
Select the correct irregular plural.
meta.hint:
A noun names a person, animal, place or thing. You can add -s or -es to most nouns to show that there is more than one person, animal, place or thing. Example - apple - apples, bus - buses
Some nouns change their spelling to show more than one person, animal, place or thing. These nouns do not follow a rule. You have to remember what spelling to use to show more than one. Example - man - men
A common noun names a type of person, animal, place or thing. A common noun starts with a lowercase letter, unless it is the first word in a sentence. Example - cat, girl, park
meta.question: Identify the common noun.

meta.hint:
Conjunctions (like and, but, or and so) are used to put words and sentences together. Use 'and' to show that things go together.
Example - 1) Greg and Kate are playing a game. 2) We went to the zoo, and we saw some lions.
Use 'but' to show that things are different or opposite.
Example - I want to read, but my sister wants to play with me.
Use 'or' to show a choice.
Example - 1) Do you want to go to the zoo or the park? 2) Aaron can ride his bike to school, or he can walk.
Use 'so' to show that something happens because of something else.
Example - Today is my birthday, so my mum baked a cake.
meta.question: Complete the sentence with the best conjuction.

meta.hint:
Some verbs tell you about something that is going to happen. These verbs tell you about the future. They use the word 'will'.
Example - 1) We will walk to the park next week. 2) The party will start soon.
meta.question: Identify the sentence that tells about future.
Complete the sentence in the past tense.
meta.hint:
Past tense verbs tell about something that has already happened. To make a past tense verb, you usually just add -ed.
walk → walked Example - We walked to the shops yesterday.
If the verb already ends with an -e, you just add -d.
bake → baked Example - Jane baked a cake last week.

blocks.name: Form and use regular past tense

meta.hint:
Some verbs tell you about something that has already happened. These verbs tell you about the past. They usually end in -ed.
Example - We walked to the park yesterday. Example - We looked at the flowers there.
Some verbs are irregular in the past tense. These verbs change their spelling to tell you about the past. You have to remember what spelling to use.
Example - We saw some ducks at the park. (See -> Saw) Example - We ate lunch on the grass. (Eat -> Ate)
meta.question: Select the sentence with irregular past tense.

meta.hint:
Some verbs tell you about something that has already happened. These verbs tell you about the past. They usually end in -ed.
Example - We walked to the shops yesterday. Example - The show started last week.
Some verbs tell you about something that is happening now. These verbs tell you about the present. They usually have no end, or they end in -s.
We walk to school today. Example - The show starts now.
Some verbs tell you about something that is going to happen. These verbs tell you about the future. They use the word will.
We will walk to the park next week. Example - The party will start soon.
meta.question: Identify the sentence which tells about past.
Complete the sentence with the correct present tense form.
meta.hint:
Use 'is' if the sentence is about one person, animal, place, or, thing.
Example - Richard is funny. Example - It is brittle.
Use 'are' if the sentence is about more than one person, animal, place or thing. Also, use 'are' if the sentence is about you.
Example - Jake and Ron are late. Example -We are behind you. Example - You are so pretty.
Use 'am' if the sentence is about I. Example - I am not going there.

Some verbs tell you about something that has already happened. These verbs tell you about the past. They usually end in -ed.
Example - We walked to the shops yesterday. Example - The show started last week.
Some verbs tell you about something that is happening now. These verbs tell you about the present. They usually have no end, or they end in -s.
Example - We walk to school today. Example - The show starts now.
Some verbs tell you about something that is going to happen. These verbs tell you about the future. They use the word will.
Example - We will walk to the park next week. Example - The party will start soon.
meta.question: Select the sentence which tells about present.

meta.hint:
Some words tell you what a person, animal, or thing does. These words are called verbs.
Example The cat jumps. Example - We play.
meta.question: Complete the sentence with the action verb to match the picture.

meta.hint:
Some words tell you where something is or where something happens.
Example - The cat is under the bed. She jumps on the bed.
A few examples are above, behind, beside, between, in, in front of, inside, next to, on, outside, and under.
meta.question: Select the preposition to complete the sentence.

meta.meta_question: Complete the sentence to match the picture.
meta.hint:
A noun names a person, animal, place, or, thing.
Some nouns name a person. Example - girl, boy.
Some nouns name an animal. Example - duck, cat.
Some nouns name a place. Example - park, school.
Some nouns name a thing. Example - hat, train
meta.question: Identify whether the given sentence is a statement, a question, a command or an exclamation.

meta.hint:
A sentence has a naming part and an action part. It shows complete thought.
eg. My sister got very good marks. eg. I do exercise every morning.
A sentence starts with a capital letter. It ends with a full stop (.) or another end mark.
meta.question: Find and select the complete sentence.
Identify whether the part of sentence is action part or naming part?
meta.hint:
Every sentence has a naming part and an action part.
The naming part tells who or what the sentence is about. eg. That building is so tall. eg. Rocky is sad.
The action part tells something about the naming part. The action part can tell what the naming part does. It can also tell what the naming part is like. eg. That building is so tall. eg. Rocky is sad.

blocks.name: Naming part or Action part of the sentence?
Who, What, When, Why or Where?

meta.hint:
Use who to ask about a person. eg. Who saw the bird first?
Use what to ask about a thing. eg. What do birds eat?
Use when to ask about a time. eg. When do birds sleep?
Use where to ask about a place. eg. Where is the bird's nest?
Use why to ask for a reason. eg. Why do birds sing?
meta.question: Complete the sentence with the best question word?

meta.hint:
An adjective is a word that tells you about a person, animal, place or thing. Some adjectives tell you what kind.
Example -He sees a big lorry. Example -We have a green ball.
Some adjectives tell you how many.
Example - Kim sees two apples. Example - I have three English books.
meta.question: Identify the correct adjective.
Type the spelling of the word.
Can you type the spelling of the word?
